titleStmt.title: Approximation and Rendering of Volume Data Using Wavelet Transforms

analytic.title: Approximation and Rendering of Volume Data Using Wavelet Transforms

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: A method is presented to obtain a unique shape description of an object b y using wavelet transforms. Wavelet transform is a new signal analysis technique which decomposes a signal using a family of functions having a local property in both time and frequency domains. A multiresolution expression of 3D volume data was first obtained by applying 3D orthogonal wavelet transforms, with the shape then being approximated with a relatively small number of 3D orthogonal functions using only the significant functions. I n addition, the resolution of the approximation can be varied point by point using the local property of the wavelets. The method is applied t o real volume data, i.e., facial range data and M R images of a human head, and typical results are shown.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: To realize computer object recognition, threedimensional (3D) object information must be obtained, with conventional computer vision techniques, such as stereo matching and laser range scanning, providing this information in the form of range images. To analyze the context of a range image, it is necessary to transform it into some kind of symbolic shape description. [l, 2, 3, 4, 51 However, in order t o handle a range image using symbolic processing, the range data must be significantly compressed or converted into a hierarchical expression since it is constructed from a multitude of numeric values.

In previous work 61, a range image approximation (Blobby model) 6, 7, 8 , 91 was used t o feasibly apnumber of primitives. However, the nonlinear problem of fitting a Blobby model to the range data required immense calculation time and only provided a local solution, and therefore we corId not obtain a unique shape description of the give.1 range data. Even though a unique shape description of a 3D object was previously accomplished usin,; an orthogonal series such as a Fourier series [lO] or by spherical liarmonics [ll], these expressions were iccomprehensible to human perception; thus not being suitable as a shape description method for a 3D object. Furthermore, these shape description methods were not able to approximate volume data containing inside in-by a hierarchical vo I umetric shape description model proximate an o b ject's shape with a relatively small formation of the object. Because of the wide use of computer tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance MR) techniques, volume data has recently been han-6 led usin a common 3D expression method (polygons or boxel$, however, the enormous size of this data makes it difficult to computer process. An efficient method to compress volume data without losing the object's fundamental shape is therefore desired. This led t o the present paper which proposes a method t o approximate volume data with 3D functions using wavelet transforms.[l2, 13, 141 Wavelet transforms constitute a new technique for signal analysis, i.e., decomposing a signal on a family of functions having a local property in both time and frequency domains. By applying 3D orthogonal wavelet transforms to a volume data, we can express any 3D object as a summation of orthogonal functions (scaling functions and wavelets); thereby enabling a multiresolution expression[l4] of the object to be made. Hence if we use only the significant fuiictions, we can smoothly approximate the object's shape using a relatively small number of functions without spoiling the fundamental shape. The multiresolution expression in conjunction with the local property of the wavelets provides comprehensible images for human perception and is suitable for use as an object shape description method. In addition, the resolution of the approximation can be varied point by point using the local property of the wavelets.

In the presented shape description method, surface patches and voxels, which were previously the main elements used in computer graphics to express a complex object, are not utilized. Instead, we apply 3D wavelet transforms t o real volume data, and then show the method's efficiency to describe 3D shapes.

div.head: Multiresolution Expression and Or-
div.p: A multiresolution expression of a function f (z) consists of a hierarchy of approximation spaces of f(z), defined as averages on different scales. The multiresolution vector space V 2 j has the following properties.

div.head: Application t o a Panoramic Range
div.p: The 3D wavelet transform was applied t,o real binary volume data which was generated from a panoramic range image of a famous movie actor (figure 6). The volume data has 2,097,152 boxels (128 x 128 x 128), with the va.lue of each boxel being 255 for the inside the liead and 0 for the outside. The filtering operation was applied three times and a multiresohlion expression of the volume data was obtained (figure 7). Tlie culculation time was about two minutes on a €IP9000/730. From these coefficients, me can reconstruct tlie cont,inuous approximation of tlie volume function at the original resolution as follows:

We can express the volume data with isosurfaces of a threshold value T which are defined by an implicit function: ifli(z, y, z ) = T. (17) i=l This equation has a similar representation as the definition of a Blobby model [6,7,8,9], and can be rendered by a ray tracing technique.

[l6] Figure 8(a-f) shows the isosurfaces of T = 128 for volume data of when using different numbers of functions. Notice as the number of functions increases, the detail of the face is restored. By using the local property of wavelets, we can approximate a particular place in detail. Figure 9 is a partially enhanced image which was generated by adding the functions around the left ear of figure 8 f)

div.head: Application to MR Images
div.p: Another application example used a series of 115 slices of magnetic resonance (MR) images (figure 10). Volume data of 128 x 128 x 128 boxels was generated from these images and a multiresolution expression having the same structure of figure 7 was generated. which are generated using 2,048 significant functions. Since it is very important to show the inside structure of volume data in cases of MR imaging volume data, an image showing the cross sections with two planar surfaces was made as shown in figure ll(b). When the volume value of a point, a t which the ray intersected with the planer surface, exceeded the threshold value T, a color corresponding to the volume value was given to the point. Figure ll(c-f) shows subsequent changes in image quality as the number of the functions increase.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: We have shown that one can approximate an object's shape with a relatively small number of 3D functions by applying wavelet transforms to the volume data. In this shape description method, a complicated object can be expressed without using the concepts of surface patches and voxels; previously indispensable elements for conventional volume visualization methods. A multiresolution expression of the object was also obtained; thereby enabling future analysis of the object's structure. By sorting the functions in order of their significance, a good approximation in proportion t o the number of functions is obtained. The local property of the wavelets was useful to change the resolution of the expression point by point. By using these properties, it is expected that an efficient method can be developed to transport volume data via computer networks, i.e., a rough approximation can be initially sent, followed by obtaining enhanced to the functions of figure 8 a). As expected, only t 6 e area around the left ear is 8 nely approximated. details a t selected places. A psychological volume data compression method which emphasizes t specific place on an image, e.g., the eyes on a face, may also be possible.

It is realized our presented hlR imag-; (isosurfaces and cross sections) do not adequately sliow the inside information of the volume; hence research is being focused on developing a better expression method. In the presented method, the volume value of the object is expressed as a 3D function; thus the gradient of the volume value can easily be analytically obtained and will be useful in various future rendering methods. Further, reconstruction of discrete voxel data from the presented description is very systematically performed by the inverse filtering operation of figure 4. This subsequently allows conventional voxel based volume visualization techniques[l7] to be applied to our shape descriptions.
